description:
Sinocyclocheilus grahami is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the genus Sinocyclocheilus, which is endemic to China. It is a member of the family Cyprinidae, commonly known as the carp family.

Sinocyclocheilus grahami is a relatively small fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 10-15 centimeters. It has a distinctive body shape, with a rounded, compressed profile and a large, terminal mouth. The fish's coloration is typically a mix of brown, olive, and yellowish hues, with a pale underside.

This species is found in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River basin, primarily in the provinces of Yunnan and Sichuan. It prefers cool, clear, and well-oxygenated streams and rivers, often inhabiting areas with rocky or gravel substrates.

Sinocyclocheilus grahami is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, algae, and small invertebrates. It plays a role in the aquatic ecosystem as a consumer and a food source for larger predatory species.

This fish species is of particular interest to scientists due to its evolutionary adaptations, as the genus Sinocyclocheilus is known for its diverse and specialized cave-dwelling species. The study of Sinocyclocheilus grahami and its relatives can provide insights into the processes of adaptation and speciation in isolated freshwater environments.
